channel.title: World
channel.description: The Washington Post World section provides information and analysis of breaking world news stories. In addition to our world news and video, Post World News offers discussions and blogs on major international news and economic issues.

item.title: Live updates: Israel and U.S. condemn ICC arrest warrants; other nations vow to enforce
item.dc:creator: Kareem Fahim, Vivian Ho, Frances Vinall, Adam Taylor
item.description: The court issued warrants for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the former defense minister “for crimes against humanity and war crimes.” It also issued a warrant for a Hamas military leader.

item.title: Netanyahu calls ICC’s decision ‘antisemitic,’ ‘distorted’
item.dc:creator: Sammy Westfall, Alon Rom

item.title: Senate Democrats force Israel weapons vote, citing Biden inaction
item.dc:creator: Abigail Hauslohner
item.description: The Senate ultimately voted down the measure, brought by Sen. Bernie Sanders and Democratic allies, to block the sale of some U.S.-made weapons to Israel.

item.title: Senate Democrats force Israel weapons vote, citing Biden inaction
item.dc:creator: Abigail Hauslohner

item.title: Russia fires new ballistic missile at Ukraine as Putin threatens West
item.dc:creator: David Stern, Karen DeYoung, Ellen Francis, Mary Ilyushina
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin warned the United States and Ukraine’s other partners that the weapon could be deployed against their interests as well.

item.title: ICC arrest warrants accuse Netanyahu, Gallant of war crimes in Gaza
item.dc:creator: Kareem Fahim, Louisa Loveluck, Alon Rom
item.description: The International Criminal Court said the alleged crimes include starvation as a method of warfare, murder, persecution and other inhuman acts.

item.title: Arrest warrant would apply to 124 countries, but not the United States
item.dc:creator: Adam Taylor

item.title: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said Canada would abide by the rulings of the International Criminal...
item.dc:creator: Mikhail Klimentov

item.title: The United States “fundamentally rejects” the decision by the ICC to issue arrest warrants for senior...
item.dc:creator: Karen DeYoung

item.title: U.S. case against Adani targets a close ally of Indian prime minister
item.dc:creator: Gerry Shih, Karishma Mehrotra, Anant Gupta
item.description: Adani is seen as an arm of Indian domestic and foreign policy — and a proxy for Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

item.title: Yoav Gallant, named in ICC warrants, says decision sets ‘dangerous precedent’
item.dc:creator: Mikhail Klimentov, Alon Rom

item.title: A spokesman for the French Ministry for Europe and Foreign Affairs said Thursday that France supports...
item.dc:creator: Mikhail Klimentov, Ellen Francis

item.title: Iceland volcano spews glowing lava in seventh eruption in a year
item.dc:creator: Victoria Bisset
item.description: The eruption — the 10th on the Reykjanes Peninsula since 2021 — began with little warning. The nearby town of Grindavik and the Blue Lagoon were evacuated.

item.title: The Irish Foreign Ministry published a statement Thursday in support of the International Criminal Court.
item.dc:creator: Mikhail Klimentov

item.title: Israel condemns ICC decision as the Netherlands vows to enforce it
item.dc:creator: Vivian Ho

item.title: Abdullah Hammoud, mayor of Dearborn, Michigan, where there is a large Palestinian American population, posted on...
item.dc:creator: Vivian Ho

item.title: ICC says it found ‘reasonable grounds’ to blame Netanyahu, Gallant for war crimes
item.dc:creator: Kareem Fahim, Hari Raj, Vivian Ho

item.title: World’s tallest and shortest women meet for afternoon tea in London
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Hassan
item.description: The world’s tallest woman, Rumeysa Gelgi, met with the shortest woman, Jyoti Amge, bonding over their shared interests while celebrating their differences.

item.title: Can Lebanon’s army secure the south? A cease-fire deal could depend on it.
item.dc:creator: Kareem Fahim, Suzan Haidamous, Mohamad El Chamaa

item.title: Billionaire Gautam Adani indicted in New York in alleged bribery scheme
item.dc:creator: Shayna Jacobs, Bryan Pietsch
item.description: Indian energy mogul Gautam Adani, an ally of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, was indicted in New York on bribery charges involving solar energy supply contracts.

item.title: Paws up! Police find shoe thief at a kindergarten is actually a weasel.
item.dc:creator: Naomi Schanen
item.description: Police in southwest Japan installed cameras after nearly two dozen children’s shoes went missing from Gosho Kodomo-en kindergarten in Fukuoka. The culprit? A weasel.

item.title: Fearing war, Georgia chooses a return to Russia’s embrace
item.dc:creator: Mary Ilyushina
item.description: The pro-Russian ruling party claimed victory in an election rife with violations with the message that angering Moscow risks turning Georgia into another Ukraine.

item.title: Who is Gautam Adani? Indian billionaire hit with fraud charges in U.S.
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch, Niha Masih, Rachel Pannett
item.description: Adani, an Indian business magnate and one of the richest men in Asia, faces new allegations of fraud to secure solar energy supply contracts.

item.title: Brazil marks Black Consciousness Day, a new holiday, for first time
item.dc:creator: Sammy Westfall
item.description: The holiday marks the anniversary of the death of Zumbi, a key figure in Black resistance to slavery in Brazil.

item.title: Can Lebanon’s army secure the south? A cease-fire deal could depend on it.
item.dc:creator: Kareem Fahim, Suzan Haidamous, Mohamad El Chamaa
item.description: The readiness of Lebanon’s army is a matter of growing urgency as the Biden administration makes a new push for an end to the war between Israel and Hezbollah.

item.title: U.S. Embassy in Kyiv closes over attack fears after Ukraine strikes Russia
item.dc:creator: David Stern
item.description: The announcement came a day after Ukraine used U.S.-supplied missiles to strike inside Russia, raising fears of retaliation against the capital.

item.title: What are antipersonnel mines, widely banned weapons Biden is giving Ukraine?
item.dc:creator: Leo Sands
item.description: President Joe Biden agreed to provide antipersonnel land mines to Ukraine as Russian troops advance. The weapon is banned in over 160 countries.

item.title: What to know about ‘Rust’ premiere, three years after fatal shooting
item.dc:creator: Victoria Bisset
item.description: Alec Baldwin’s Western “Rust” premiered in Poland on Wednesday, three years after cinematographer Halyna Hutchins was fatally shot on set.

item.title: Media publisher Jimmy Lai defiant as he takes the stand in Hong Kong
item.dc:creator: Shibani Mahtani, Vic Chiang
item.description: The sentencing of pro-democracy activists and the trial of media mogul Jimmy Lai show how Hong Kong’s courts are becoming a tool for repression, analysts say.

item.title: Ugandan opposition politician Kizza Besigye kidnapped and jailed, wife says
item.dc:creator: Katharine Houreld, Rael Ombuor
item.description: Besigye was arrested in Kenya and taken across the border to a Ugandan military jail, according to his wife, Winnie Byanyima, head of the U.N. HIV/AIDS program.

item.title: How Trump’s tariffs could spark a trade war and ‘Europe’s worst economic nightmare’
item.dc:creator: Ellen Francis, Kate Brady
item.description: European countries could be among those hardest hit if Trump follows through on tariffs. The European Union says it wants to negotiate but is prepared to retaliate.

item.title: Son of Norway’s crown princess arrested on suspicion of rape, police say
item.dc:creator: Rachel Pannett
item.description: Marius Borg Hoiby has no royal title or duties, but as the stepson of the heir to the throne, his arrest has cast a cloud over Norway’s popular royal family.

item.title: How a brutally repressive African country freely raises money in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Houreld
item.description: Eritrea’s embassy has helped raise millions of dollars to promote the interests of the brutally repressive country. Its ruling party is under U.S. sanctions.

item.title: Biden drifts off the world stage after Brazil’s G-20
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor
item.description: The trip that was supposed to be the U.S. president’s swan song seemed to underscore his status as a lame duck.

item.title: Biden approves antipersonnel mines for Ukraine, undoing his own policy
item.dc:creator: Michael Birnbaum, Alex Horton
item.description: The controversial White House move to send Kyiv land mines comes as Russia’s advances in eastern Ukraine threaten to overwhelm front-line defenses.

item.title: Ukraine fires U.S.-made ATACMS missiles into Russia for first time
item.dc:creator: Siobhán O'Grady, David Stern, Serhiy Morgunov, Missy Ryan
item.description: Ukraine’s ATACMS strike in Russia’s Bryansk region marks an intensification of the war amid uncertainty over Donald Trump’s return to the White House.

item.title: Pentagon misstated how Special Operations troops died off Cyprus last year
item.dc:creator: Kyle Rempfer
item.description: A Special Operations helicopter deployed in response to fighting in Gaza crashed during target practice, not aerial refueling, as the Pentagon said last year.

item.title: Iraq bans alcohol in hotels and clubs, bringing country close to near-total ban
item.dc:creator: Mustafa Salim, Sammy Westfall
item.description: Alcohol has long been easily accessible in Baghdad, but a crackdown in recent years has made booze much more difficult to find.
